awd_titl_txt: EAGER: FEWSTERN: US-China Food-Energy-Water Systems Transdisciplinary Environmental Research Network
awd_abstract_narration:
Food production and quality are closely linked to use of energy and water and overall ecosystem health. As demand for food, energy, and water all increase due to increased population and changes in diet, it is essential to consider the balance of energy, water, and land resource uses to achieve food and nutrition security, economic goals, and essential ecosystem functions and services. Typical research projects are rather narrowly-focused and carried out by individual disciplines. However, in order to address broad challenges and enable sustainable solutions, collaboration among different disciplines is essential. This grant aims to increase the understanding among different academic disciplines in the US and China of approaches for addressing increasingly important challenges related to competition among food, energy, and water systems (FEWS). Typically, development of technologies, policies, and management systems for food, energy, and water systems are done without considering various tradeoffs that may occur, competing demands for resources for each of these basic human needs, and potential conflicts in policies that regulate each of them. The goal of this project is to enable networking and meetings among different science and engineering disciplines to identify food, energy, and water systems to be studied holistically so that increases in productivity and efficiency can be achieved for systems that provide for increasing demands for these resources. The project will enable scientists and engineers to develop teams to address specific FEW systems and to develop interdisciplinary concepts.

This project will support activities that will enable innovative ideas to be developed through interactions among different disciplines involved in various aspects of food, energy and water research. These will range from technological to social and policy innovations for FEWS program development beyond national borders, and contribute concepts for local, national and global solutions to achieve sustainable intensification of natural resource exploitation and use. The project will establish a US-China crosscutting research coordination network to (i) identify transdisciplinary environmental grand challenge research opportunities at the FEWS nexus, (ii) develop a framework to overcome hurdles to interdisciplinary research both between and among collaborating US and China researchers, and (iii) establish model platforms for education, training, communication and efficacy evaluations of the outputs of international cooperation. Over a 2-year period of strategic research planning, identification of grand challenges, and teaming workshops, FEWSTERN will generate technical whitepapers and guidance documents supporting international collaboration and research. US and Chinese graduate students will communicate project outcomes and goals via social media outlets. Novel system level research will generate opportunities for academia-industry partnerships at the FEWS nexus.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: Innovations at the Nexus of Food-Energy-

por.por_cntn:
The FEWSTERN project created a research coordination network (RCN) between the US and China with the goal to identify Food-Energy-Water (FEW) nexus research grand challenges. A total of 91 US and Chinese institutions and organizations, including universities, non-academic research institutions, industry, government agencies, and NGOs, participated in a series of workshops and symposia with the goal to discuss and identify FEW nexus research grand challenges at the local, the regional and the global scale. The project encouraged the various stakeholders and researchers, including undergraduate and graduate students, (i) to identify hurdles that limit an individual’s ability to fully integrate into truly transdisciplinary FEW nexus research programs, (ii) to consider the rewards to be gained by extending her/his research portfolio to encompass a transdisciplinary, international FEW nexus-focused research agenda, and (iii) to recognize technical advances and future needs for a forward-looking FEW nexus research agenda. The project stimulated researchers from various disciplines to rethink their typically siloed research approaches, embrace transdisciplinary and system-level strategies in their future research activities, and collaborate with various stakeholders to solve real-world problems in the context of scale-crossing interactions that determine the consequences of current practices for the sustainability of FEW systems. The project identified a number of perceived FEW nexus grand challenges and emphasized both top-down and bottom-up strategies for incorporating existing and future project results into a transdisciplinary framework. Researchers were highly motivated to participate in team building efforts and FEWSTERN has facilitated new collaborative FEW nexus-directed research activities within and between the US and China. The project brought together stakeholder and researchers with diverse backgrounds, established new connections between various research disciplines, and served as a seed for transdisciplinary systems thinking research and innovative ideas that address the FEW nexus. In education, FEWSTERN developed a FEW system-focused teaching curriculum (i.e., nexus of food, energy and water) and several training modules (e.g., study abroad and undergraduate research programs) tailored to stimulate students’ interest in transdisciplinary FEW nexus research. The curriculum has been recognized by the University of Tennessee as a teaching effort supporting the United Nations’ Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). In the long term, this curriculum will contribute to training the next-generation workforce with global leadership ambitions capable of accomplishing SDGs through international and transdisciplinary collaboration. The FEWSTERN project recruited 21 students from Chinese partner universities into doctoral programs at the University of Tennessee. The students engaged in the RCN project by facilitating interactions and collaborations between Chinese and US faculty, research groups, and institutions, and by conducting transdisciplinary FEW system research activities. In outreach, the FEWSTERN team engaged government and industry stakeholders to ensure the involvement of key FEW system stakeholders in implementing a proactive FEW nexus research agenda that ultimately benefits all people.

FEWSTERN project established a US-China RCN, which serves as a blueprint for an international FEW system network that can be expanded to include other nations, or its framework can be adopted by others to build independent international RCNs. The FEWSTERN RCN benefits the NSF mission by facilitating international, transdisciplinary research collaborations and generating a globally engaged workforce for implementing FEW nexus solutions at local, regional and global scales.
